articles.headline: Virginia to Remove Suspect Guardrails
articles.snippet: Rail heads made by Trinity Industries, meant to reduce damage in a collision, are suspected of having a defect and have been banned by 13 states.
articles.abstract: Rail heads made by Trinity Industries, meant to reduce damage in a collision, are suspected of having a defect and have been banned by 13 states.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adding to pressure on the guardrail manufacturer Trinity Industries, Virginia said on Monday that it planned to remove the company’s products after it failed to meet a state deadline to supply documentation for new crash testing.
articles.byline: By Aaron M. Kessler and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Twitter’s Revenue Sharply Rises, but Its Usage Stalls
articles.snippet: Revenue at the social network surpassed Wall Street expectations, but Twitter is still losing money.
articles.abstract: Revenue at the social network surpassed Wall Street expectations, but Twitter is still losing money.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Dick Costolo, Twitter’s chief executive, has been sprucing up the social network this year. So far, however, the renovations don’t seem to be flashy enough to bring in many newcomers or persuade the veterans to return more frequently.

articles.headline: Report Reveals Wider Tracking of Mail in U.S.
articles.snippet: The Postal Service approved nearly 50,000 requests last year from law enforcement agencies to secretly track the mail of ordinary Americans for use in criminal and national security investigations.
articles.abstract: The Postal Service approved nearly 50,000 requests last year from law enforcement agencies to secretly track the mail of ordinary Americans for use in criminal and national security investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a rare public accounting of its mass surveillance program, the United States Postal Service reported that it approved nearly 50,000 requests last year from law enforcement agencies and its own internal inspection unit to secretly monitor the mail of Americans for use in criminal and national security investigations.

articles.headline: Wish to Do More in Ebola Fight Meets Reality in Liberia
articles.snippet: Health workers in Liberia and elsewhere in West Africa are finding they have to ration care, operating under constraints they often find frustrating.
articles.abstract: Health workers in Liberia and elsewhere in West Africa are finding they have to ration care, operating under constraints they often find frustrating.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUAKOKO, Liberia — Garmai Sayon endured more than anyone should have to bear. First, her husband died at the Ebola treatment center here, falling ill after rushing to help a stranger who had collapsed in their village. Five days later, their child — a 1-year-old boy whose two older siblings had been lost earlier to illness and accident — died in her arms while she was delirious from the disease.

articles.headline: E.C.B. Stress Tests Seen as Bolstering Confidence in Banks
articles.snippet: The results of the European Central Bank’s examination of banks show that regulators did a fairly competent job of bolstering Europe’s financial footing, analysts say.
articles.abstract: The results of the European Central Bank’s examination of banks show that regulators did a fairly competent job of bolstering Europe’s financial footing, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: If five years is an unwisely long time for a person to skip a proper checkup, it is an eternity for a $40 trillion banking sector displaying many signs of ill health.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Comment on Jobs Raises Eyebrows on Wall St.
articles.snippet: A comment by the presumptive 2016 presidential candidate that corporations don’t create jobs causes unease among some of Mrs. Clinton’s business allies.
articles.abstract: A comment by the presumptive 2016 presidential candidate that corporations don’t create jobs causes unease among some of Mrs. Clinton’s business allies.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Senate Hopeful Finds Business Résumé Cuts 2 Ways
articles.snippet: David Perdue, who is running against the Democrat Michelle Nunn, has had to defend his record as a senior corporate executive, including the outsourcing of jobs.
articles.abstract: David Perdue, who is running against the Democrat Michelle Nunn, has had to defend his record as a senior corporate executive, including the outsourcing of jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARTERSVILLE, Ga. — In a year when Republicans have been able to harness economic anxiety to their distinct advantage, the Senate candidacy of the Republican David Perdue in Georgia has shown that voter dread can cut both ways.

articles.headline: Mexico’s State-Owned Oil Giant, Pemex, Is in Uncharted Waters
articles.snippet: Pemex hopes to shed its reputation as a lumbering oil monopoly and to remake itself into a modern company that can compete with the world’s biggest firms.
articles.abstract: Pemex hopes to shed its reputation as a lumbering oil monopoly and to remake itself into a modern company that can compete with the world’s biggest firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA MURALLA IV, Gulf of Mexico — The computer screens lining the bubblelike control room on this giant floating platform monitor pressure levels in a narrow shaft cut through bedrock to a reservoir of valuable natural gas three miles below sea level.
